channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Disputing U.S. General, Afghans Say Taliban Control Kunduz
item.description: Gen. John F. Campbell, the American military commander, told the Senate Armed Services Committee that Afghan forces had retaken the city.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: Russian Violations of Airspace Seen as Unwelcome Test by the West
item.description: Two Russian warplanes violated Turkish airspace over the weekend, raising concerns about Russian aggression beyond mere saber rattling.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Russian fighter jet taking off from an air base in Syria. A number of Western countries have complained in recent years about Russian planes approaching their airspace.

item.title: Disputing U.S. General, Afghans Say Taliban Control Kunduz
item.description: Gen. John F. Campbell, the American military commander, told the Senate Armed Services Committee that Afghan forces had retaken the city.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: E.U. to Share Data on Multinational Companies’ Tax Deals
item.description: The move is intended to address anger over benefits that have been granted to companies like Starbucks and Amazon.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Open Source: French TV Celebrates Female Hosts With Ad Criticized as Sexist
item.description: French women objected to an ad that seemed to suggest that working women had transformed households into nightmarish hellscapes of undone chores.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Toll of Chemical Weapons for One Young Syrian Family
item.description: The residents of the town of Marea had already survived crackdowns, tanks, infantry attacks, airstrikes and cluster munitions. But something about an attack this summer was different.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abu Anas, who along with his family was wounded when an artillery shell thought to contain a chemical agent hit their home in Marea, Syria. He now spends much of his day in bed, coughing, at the small apartment his father-in-law rents in Turkey.

item.title: Survivor of Jerusalem Stabbing Recounts Attack on Her Family
item.description: Odel Bennett’s husband was killed along with a rabbi after a Palestinian assailant attacked the family in Jerusalem’s Old City.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Friends and relatives praying over the body of Aharon Bennett, who was killed in a knife attack, during his funeral on Sunday in Jerusalem.

item.title: General Takes Responsibility for Afghan Hospital Airstrike
item.description: Gen. John F. Campbell said the hospital was “mistakenly struck,” and said it resulted from “a U.S. decision made within the U.S. chain of command.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Critic's Notebook: Stuttgart Struggles to House the Migrants It Embraces
item.description: Migration has long been an engine of growth for the German city, and integration the bedrock of civic pride. But problems include a dearth of affordable housing.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Schlossplatz in Stuttgart, Germany. Forty percent of Stuttgart’s 600,000 residents come from abroad, twice the national average

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Refugee Crisis That Could Draw the U.S. and Europe Closer
item.description: The challenge of handling the influx of those fleeing the Taliban in Syria and Afghanistan may prod Western governments to learn from their past mistakes.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan and other refugees at an arrival center in Dortmund, Germany, in September.

item.title: Russia Military’s Actions in Syria Cause Rift With Turkey
item.description: Moscow is bombing rebel groups backed by the government in Ankara, and its warplanes have flown into Turkish airspace, undercutting President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, right, with Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission, in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Environmentalists Praise Wildlife Measures in Trans-Pacific Trade Pact
item.description: Provisions of the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement would protect wildlife covered by an existing international agreement, and provide for cross-border cooperation on enforcement.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Confiscated elephant tusks in Thailand. Environmentalists said the trade pact could help diminish the illegal trade in certain plants and animals.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Putin’s Motives in Syria
item.description: If Russia had really been eager for peace, it could have exerted pressure on the Assad government before the civil war.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin in Russia with military officers.

item.title: Charge for Plastic Bags in Britain Draws Applause, Anger and Humor
item.description: The British government has imposed a charge for use of plastic shopping bags that litter the landscape and take a thousand years to decompose.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Plastic bags in London. Last year, about 7.6 billion single-use plastic bags were handed out by major supermarkets.

item.title: Top United Nations Official Is Accused in Bribery Scheme
item.description: John W. Ashe, the former president of the United Nations General Assembly, was named in a criminal complaint outlining a scheme that involved more than $1 million in payments from sources in China.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA, SOMINI SENGUPTA and BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: John W. Ashe speaking during a session of the General Assembly in 2013.

item.title: Car Bombs in Yemen Hit Aden Hotel and Building Used by Persian Gulf Troops
item.description: Senior government officials were not injured in the hotel explosion, but a security official in Aden said at least 18 people were killed in the soldiers’ building.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Claims of British Pedophile Ring Are Cast Into Doubt
item.description: The BBC says many of the claims made by a central witness in the case cannot be confirmed with public records.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Data Transfer Pact Between U.S. and Europe Is Ruled Invalid
item.description: The decision by the European Court of Justice throws into doubt how tech giants like Facebook and Google can use digital data from millions of users.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Max Schrems, second from left, before the European Court of Justice ruling in Luxembourg on Tuesday related to his case.

item.title: Cautiously, Iranians Reclaim Public Spaces and Liberties Long Suppressed
item.description: A more moderate president, Hassan Rouhani, and a nuclear accord have many hopeful Iranians trying to take back the streets, not politically but socially and culturally.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A concert by the pop singer Sina Hejazi at the Milad Tower in Tehran. Public concerts have become more frequent in Iran even though music is still denounced by conservative clerics.

item.title: Pakistan Moves to Quiet Outcry Against Saudi Arabia Over Hajj Stampede
item.description: Scores of Pakistani pilgrims were killed in the disaster, and many families still do not know what happened to their relatives.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Iqbal Bano wept at her home in Peshawar, Pakistan, while holding a picture of her son Sher Afzal Khan, who was killed last month in the stampede at the annual hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
